Dear Kari Ann Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-243-9743.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a
youth’s background or appearance or mental state. Yelling,
threats, ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that Youth A was called "fat bitch" repeatedly by Staff
1.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant 1 could not be contacted as there was no contact
information provided.
On 12/15/2023, allegations were discussed with Consultant 1.
Due to Youth A being removed from Lincoln and placed at
Wolverine Vassar, Consultant 1 had to complete the interview with
Youth A.
On 12/18/2023, allegations were discussed with Administrator 1.
No new information was provided.
The following interviews were conducted face to face at the facility
on 12/27/2023:
Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D all reported Staff 1 and Youth A
were engaged in a back-and-forth argument (date unknown),
during shower time. All three youth reported Youth A was
aggravated about showers taking too long. All reported Staff 1
called Youth A a “bitch” and Youth A had called Staff 1 numerous
names which resulted in Staff 1 name calling back.
Youth C reported Youth A called Staff 1 a “fat bitch” and Staff 1
stated back, “I can say the same about you.”
2

The following interviews were conducted via telephone on
1/9/2024:
Staff 2 reported she was working with Staff 1 when Youth A
became upset about showers. Youth A was upset about showers
taking longer than normal. She had yelled and screamed at other
youth and at Staff 1. Staff 2 reported she never heard Staff 1 yell
at Youth A. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 left the unit after being yelled
at by Youth A.
Staff 1 reported Youth A had been disrespectful during shower
time, ordering staff around and cussing at youth. Staff 1 attempted
to talk to her to deescalate her, but it wasn’t working. Staff 1
reported Youth A had called everyone names. Staff 1 reported she
did not call Youth A names but did go “back and forth” with her
about her behavior. Staff 1 reported Youth A wouldn’t listen to her,
so Staff 1 left the unit. Staff 1 did report she stated to Youth A that
she has an “ugly personality.” Staff 1 reported she was speaking
specifically to Youth A’s disrespect of her elders when she stated
that she had an “ugly personality.”
Staff 3 reported Youth A had not followed directions during
shower time and had yelled and cussed at everyone. Staff 3
reported Staff 1 and herself were redirecting Youth A, but she
would not listen to them. Staff 3 reported no one went “back and
forth” with Youth A. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 came in at 6:00pm
that night, 12/1/2024 and attempted to help Youth A by redirecting
her, but Youth A continued to yell and cuss. Staff 1 left the unit
when she realized Youth A was not going to listen. Staff 3
reported she did not hear Staff 1 cussing or name calling at Youth
A.
Interview conducted face to face by Consultant 1 on 12/20/2023:
Youth A reported she was not engaged in any activity and was in
her room getting ready for bed. She was waiting on her chance to
shower and became annoyed because another youth was taking
too long. Youth A did not report which youth was taking too long in
the shower. Youth A reported Staff 1 tried to talk to her and
redirect her, but she asked Staff 1 to stop talking to her. Youth A
reported Staff 1 began to get upset and slammed her hand on the
table and said, “If you think you’re gonna raise your voice at me”
and then Youth A stated she heard Staff 1 call her a “bitch”. At this
time, Youth A reported she does not know if other youth heard it.
3

Documents Reviewed:
• There is no video of the alleged incident.
• Staff 1’s personnel file was reviewed. All clearances
are in compliance with Licensing Rules for Child
Caring Institutions. Staff 1 had disciplinary Action in
her file. On 12/15/2019, Staff 1 received a 3-day
suspension for not intervening in a restraint and
failing to secure youth in their room during the
restraint. On 5/2/2023, Staff 1 received a 1-day
suspension for possessing a telephone in the control
room.
• Staff 1 was up to date with training requirements.
• The Program Statement was reviewed. The Calumet
Detention Center has a Discipline Policy that is
directed toward positive behavior development and
prohibits any form of Corporal punishment and
verbal abuse.
Analysis Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Staff 1 all reported Staff 1 and
Youth A were engaged in a back and forth argument. Although all
the youth stated Staff 1 called Youth A, “bitch,” none of the staff
reported this. Staff 1 did report she told Youth A she had an “ugly
personality.” This comment is derogatory and is not a part of
building positive behavior development.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR2022C0108032 dated 08/24/2022, CAP approved
08/30/2022.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162: Seclusion within secure and nonsecure
Section facilities; seclusion plan; prohibitions; reduction and
Description elimination.
(5) Staff may not use seclusion for discipline, punishment,
administrative convenience, retaliation, staffing shortages, or
reasons other than a temporary response to behavior that
threatens immediate harm to a youth or others.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency is using seclusion from their scheduled shower time
until waking hours.
Investigation Interviews:
The following interviews were conducted via telephone on
1/9/2024:
4

Staff 2 reported the youth in the unit take showers one by one.
Staff 2 reported the youth are locked in their rooms while other
youth take showers. Staff 2 reported showers are around 6:00pm
daily. This is their normal daily procedure.
Staff 1 reported all youth are in their locked rooms at shower time,
around 6:00pm until showers are over. Staff 1 reported the youth
don’t always come out of their rooms when showers are
completed. Showers can take until 8:00pm to complete, in which
at this time, youth are to be in their bedrooms for the night. Other
times, if showers are completed before 8:00pm, the staff will
decide if the youth can come out of their rooms for free time based
on their behaviors they exhibited in the day. Staff 1 reported if
there have not been behaviors throughout the day prohibiting their
free time, staff will then assess if permitting the youth out of their
rooms will cause problems during free time. If they feel that it
might, they do not allow them out for free time.
Staff 3 reported on 12/12/2023, Youth A was upset that other
youth were taking too long in the shower. If showers were not
completed before 8:00pm, youth were not able to come out of
their bedrooms for recreation time. Staff 3 reported showers are
done one by one. All youth are locked in their room and take
turns. Staff 3 reported they start showers at 6:00pm and when
showers are done, they may have time for recreation time. Youth
are to go into their bedrooms at 8:00pm for bedtime. Staff 3
reported she works five shifts a week and the youth are able to
come out of their room maybe 3 out of 5 nights for recreation.
Staff 3 reported the reasons the youth would not receive
recreation time is if the youth were slow to take showers and if
their behaviors were not good. Staff 3 reported recreation time
might include coloring, watching television or socializing.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via telephone on 01/16/2024
and reported youth have always been locked in their rooms while
showers were taken. Administrator 1 stated the youth take
showers one at a time and can have books in their rooms if the
clinicians allow it. Administrator 1 reported after showers, the staff
will decide what activities they may engage in.
Documents Reviewed:
• The Program Statement states:
Daily Activity Structuring: Each part of the day, from wake-up
until bedtime, shall be structured and planned. By carefully
structuring time, youth are constructively and productively
5

engaged in activities throughout the day. The daily activities
shall include attending to personal hygiene, making beds,
preparing for meals, doing work projects, eating meals,
participating in group meetings, attending school, attending
placement interviews, participating in recreational activities
and individual counseling.
The Calumet Detention Center provides a structured program of
daily recreation and leisure activities. Space is designated for
this purpose. Youth activities contain a variety of physical,
intellectual, social and cultural opportunities (both indoors and
outdoors) and are always staff supervised. The Calumet Center
has a gym, multipurpose room, outside recreational yard, pod
living rooms, an art room and ten classrooms to use for recreation.
Recreational activities are delivered within the framework
definitions for a secure Detention Facility. Recreational activities
are defined as planned, regular, and recurring set of staff
supervised leisure time events, designed to support the
youth’s Treatment Plan.
• The Pod K Girl’s Schedule was reviewed:
The afternoon schedule does not lay out specific recreational
activities scheduled.
4:30-5:30: Dinner, Task Work, Free Time
5:30-6:30: Problem Solving Group Assistance, Confirmations,
Free Time
7:30-8:00: Level 1 Curfew, Higher Privilege Level Activities
8:00-8:30: Level 2 Curfew, Higher Privilege Level Activities
8:30-9:00: Level 3 Curfew, Higher Privilege Level Activities
9:00-9:30: Level 4 Curfew, Higher Privilege Level Activities
Analysis Based upon interviews with Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 as well as
Administrator 1, the agency is in noncompliance of secluding
youth. The facility is secluding youth at shower time which starts
around 6:00pm until morning wake up at 6:00am. At times, the
youth are able to come out of their rooms if they have enough time
before their bedtime or if they have been behaviorally doing well
throughout the day. Secluding youth during shower time is not a
response to behaviors that threaten immediate harm to youth or
others and cannot be used within the program.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The agency’s schedule for the unit is a generic schedule. The
program statement states the schedule for the youth are planned
and structured so that the youth can be productive throughout the
6

day. Based on the program statement, these activities are to
provide “physical, intellectual, social and cultural opportunities.”
The agency should be documenting these recreational activities
throughout the day in alignment with the treatment goals of the
youth in their care. This would allow staff to be prepared for the
activity ahead of time, knowing the expectations, and treatment
aims as well as providing the youth with activities to look forward
to. Instead of placing the youth in seclusion during shower time,
the agency may want to incorporate these activities. All staff
interviewed did not have a planned out recreational activity. It was
something they decided during their shift.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
